author: cian riordan
content: Contrary to a lot of good advice here, I would rather be slammed busy mixing below my ideal rate than making a higher rate doing less work. I realize it's silly, but I take comfort in staying busy and keeping my 'pirate ship' afloat. I definitely have a bottom line, but I like to work with artists to meet them at what they can afford. It keeps my work portfolio diverse and my toolkit in good working order.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Gonna circle back with more later, but this is my 2 cents (I started mastering with zero clients about 9 months ago)...

Get over your fear/insecurity/weirdness of not having a portfolio. Go fuck it mode. You need to have a ton of contacts. Take a lot of shots. Of course I have no idea about what you are doing currently...but zero people I've ever talked to in this situation have taken enough shots. "I reached out to 5 people this week"...no. HUNDREDS. Most people will ignore you. But just keep going. Watch a Goggins video before you start or something haha

Really think about the experience of working with you. Is it amazing? Is it easy? Is your communication, care, intention incredible? Even things like how files are named/delivered/etc matters. You can only be as good as you are at mixing until you get more reps. But you can control how you interact and the professionalism and confidence you can inspire on the other side.

If someone lets you mix a song...are they coming back? They need to if you are going to have a business doing this!

Sorry to be prescriptive here...but I've seen this question asked of me enough to know that it's so so hugely about just brutal persistence in many aspects, assuming you have talent, etc to do the actual thing.

author: cian riordan

I was not handling things this well 10 years ago when I was your age.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Let me begin by saying that your feelings and experiences are more common than you may realize. It's alright to feel that way. Though I don't believe it's constructive to dwell on them.

It's not unusual to feel inferior when surrounded by people who are more experienced and talented than you. We've all felt this. The thing is this; you are in exactly the right place and will only benefit from engaging with this environment. Being surrounded by so many professionals and people with experience is absolutely a benefit to your development and someday you'll look back at how far you've come and be amazed by how fluent you are.

Let me drive this point home just a little more: When you were young and learning your native language, nobody put you in a room and expected you to learn the language by conversing with a bunch of inexperienced two year-olds who couldn't speak. Instead, you were surrounded by expert speakers and learned through interactions with people who were leagues ahead of you in their ability to speak the language. Learning to speak is not an easy task, but by immersing yourself in a community of experts you are on the path to mastery and in no time you'll reap the benefits of that exposure.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think it comes down to ear training, lots of repetition (mixes), and focused practice. He's very familiar with the characteristic sound that each frequency zone imparts on a given instrument and has mixed most instruments enough times to know how to achieve a given effect without having to hunt for it.

On top of that, he's probably thinking an order of magnitude higher than that because he would also understand that if he wants to accentuate a given frequency range in an instrument then he can do that by subtracting that frequency from an adjacent instrument. In this sense, I think he's listening closely to the effect that a cut has on every other instrument in a mix - not just the instrument he's subtracting from.

author: cian riordan
content:
Making the jump from working on music for local bands to making music for bigger commercial acts was obviously a big move forward. What I realized very quickly is that the process is fundamentally the same with people of all levels. You get in a room, you make a plan, and you execute it. However, when you've got a major label backing you, there's many more resources available, enabling you to spend more time (and money) making the record... although in my experience this can be both a blessing and a curse!

I assisted Eric for a few years and eventually started networking with more local Los Angeles artists and was able to mix and produce their stuff out of Eric's studio. He was very cool about letting me use the space when we weren't working on bigger projects. He set a very high standard and made it clear that anything that left our studio had to sound really, really great. After assisting and working on my own stuff for several years, Eric then hired me as his full-time main engineer and now I'm on call to work on him for any of his projects. This has been amazing in so many ways as I get to work on high-level commercial music and apply all of my own sensibilities to the process – as well as the stuff I've learned from Eric over the years.

Obviously my tale is one in a million and there's not a day that goes my where I don't realize how lucky I am. Now that I've worked full time recording music for almost 8 years, I've realized there are certain things you need to have to be successful:

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This is a constant in record making. Balancing your own thoughts with those of your client or collaborators. 

Cian is right on of course, but I’d encourage you not to think of it as binary. Almost always, there’s a version of their note that makes the song better, and it’s your job to hear it. 

In the end, it’s their record tho, and they’re the ones who will be playing it out, selling it, promoting it however they can… so they’re the ones who *need* to be happy with it in the end. 

My longtime producer & collaborator Jon Kaplan used to say “it’s your record, you can be wrong if you want to.” I give that to artists I work with now. Going in I tell them I’m going to treat you like an equal, until you tell me it’s your record and you can be wrong if you want to. 

Honestly that one idea has eased the tension on so many occasions for me.

author: BatMeckley
content:
No, definitely don’t. Please. For the love of God. Don’t. 

Master bus processing to this day still suffers from poor delay compensation, across a variety of daws. You’ll be sending him a 2 track that does not line up with your session, and the ensuing vocal you get back will not line up with what you’ve recorded. Pocket will be off. 

This has been THE SINGLE biggest nightmare in my career as a vocal producer. Please. If at all possible, leave the master off. 

(Unless you do the square wave trick at the end that will allow him to precisely align the files)

author: cian riordan
content:
I started getting serious about recording while I was in college (studying chemistry). I was playing bass in a band at the time and I was the only one that had any sort of decent recording equipment. I found myself being the guy recording all of the band's demos before we went into a 'proper studio'. Eventually, we realized my demos were sounding better than the ones we paid other people to record! Meanwhile, I started assisting (for free) at a local small recording studio and met a really great mentor. The studio was small and its business was mostly weekend warrior type stuff – nobody really notable. That being said, it was a working studio – and booked almost 6-7 days a week. The producer was the big fish in the small pond and had a great repeat clientele. Most of the music was not my cup of tea – but this proved to be a good thing as I was exposed to all sorts of different styles and it allowed me to be comfortable in genres of music which I normally wouldn't gravitate towards. It just made me comfortable around music and musicians in general.

Once I graduated and decided I wasn't going to use my chemistry degree, I ended up helping the producer build a bigger studio complex from the ground up. I learned an insane amount of stuff during this period – whether it was researching which Pro Tools system we would need to helping design the wiring layout to actually implementing it all. Ultimately, after months of hard work (and lots of borrowed money) the studio was complete and it was ready for business. I worked here for 2 years or so until I got introduced to Eric Valentine through former Street To Nowhere guitarist Matt Radosevich in Los Angeles. He needed a new full-time assistant and so I hopped at the opportunity and moved to LA – leaving behind the studio and crew I helped build (they're still going today and they're doing great).

author: Slow Hand
content:
A strong second on this. I'm not someone who interacts with many kids on a regular basis, but I've felt a similar openness and lack of inhibition during my experiences doing improv comedy. It has so much in common with what we observe in children. Finding your way back to that state of non-judgement is such a worthy pursuit.

Improv education places such an emphasis on not being precious about things, accepting what's happening in front of you, and not overthinking. Most of all, the biggest lessons were always about *listening*: Listening to your partners, listening to their intent, and listening to the audience. There is no time to plan. You just do.

I did it for two years and it was one of the most rewarding experiences of my life. The improv mindset really enriches everything else in your life once you open yourself up to it.

author: LAPhill
content:
Noah covered a lot, but a few (also stream of consciousness) thoughts to add:

There is no formula to when to take the leap. It's helpful to have some money in the bank, because it's going to take awhile for things to start happening. The more connections you have, the more in-roads you've made, the easier it will be to drum up work in music and keep the lights on. The less responsibilities and overhead you have, the easier the beginning stages of freelance life will be.

Don't think about your music career in terms of the same metrics as your day job, you're burnt out on it for a reason. So instead of "am I making what I made before," think "can I survive on this for now?" and if not, "what will get me to a place that I can afford to pursue this dream?"

Any music job can be a boon for your career, and chances are you don't know where the opportunities will come from. The Beatles became the Beatles by playing cover songs at shady clubs, honing their sound and learning to play with each other. For someone else, that would've been a mindless, thankless gig with no upside. When they started playing better gigs, they were ready and stood out because of it.

How you do anything is how you do everything - if you're an intern at a studio cleaning up trash, you may be around huge artists and engineers. If they see you as dependable, friendly, going above-and-beyond, there's a tiny chance that a life-changing opportunity could emerge. Likewise, if they see you doing a sloppy job, that's how they're going to assume you'd be in the room, too.

Very similar to Cal - but a long time ago someone told me to seek out full Rez waves of songs and use a HPF and LPF to see where they sat things in the frequency spectrum. 

Some songs the cymbals will go away when you filter below 10k, others you will need to filter to 5-6k.

Do the same on the lows filter and see what goes away. 

It’s very similar to what cal said but all you need is any EQ. And your listening for what goes away. I still do it sometimes. It’s a great practice.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Of course depends on the tempo, part, sound of the drums, aesthetic of the track - but a few things that have worked in different scenarios for me:

Create the impression of some distance to walls by sending snare (start there, maybe add other mics) to a short stereo delay. Often something like 90ms on one side, 120ms on the other. Feel it out on one side, then add some time to the other.

Try adding some fake distance to your existing room mics with a simple delay with no feedback (there’s a Steve Albini drum video on YouTube where he demonstrates this). You can delay both sides equally, or solo one side, delay it til it feels good/sounds cool, then do the other. Anything from 12ms-around 23 seems to work. From there things start to become more like a slap, but than can be cool too.

Smash up your existing rooms a bit, or a lot. Omnipressor, Devil Loc, UAD Zener, decapitator, Rough Rider (free), Arousor/Distressor in nuke, Lo-Fi. 

Send to a gated verb - Cian shared a drum session a while back with a short VintageVerb preset that’s often useful. RMX16 Non-Lins can be good too, although it’s easy to bring things into 80s territory this way.

Send to a short room verb like ocean way, SP2016, Pro-R, Valhalla Room, Raum. Sometimes from close mics, sometimes from overheads, sometimes just slapping it straight on room mics. A little distortion (Decapitator, Devil Loc) after is often helpful.

With all of these solutions, the thing that seems to help them gel with the rest of the real kit is drum bus processing - compression and/or saturation.

author: oaklandmatt

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I find it's kind of like physical exercise, your long term improvement is never linear, and as you get more experienced, you need to be smarter with how you practice if you want to progress.

What helped me improve guitar was treating it like a gym programme, pick a specific thing for a specific amount of time to practice on a Monday for example, and do that every Monday, then have another thing you practice on Tuesday etc etc. Take videos to track your progression over time. Showing up and doing it consistently over a really long time will be infinitely more valuable than a few really intense sessions here and there

If you also produce and write, you could try building your portfolio as a mixer using your own songs. You can collaborate with a singer/artist, or bring in AI vocals on the songs you wrote. 

If you record bands, you can take the recording you did and mix it even though your job was to just record. Show it to the band and see what they say, ask them if you can use it as part of your portfolio. Make sure you ask !! 

You can also build relationships with producers with similar experience level as you and offer to mix their stuff. Producers can bring you a lot of work because they work with multiple artists

If you have other stuff that you’ve mixed in the past but they are not the best representation of your current skill level then mix them again so you can include them on your portfolio.

author: Adam Thein
content:
You mentioned it already but one of the only consistent rituals for me is trying to split up the "mix assistant" type work on a different day if possible or at the very least with a break that involves leaving the room and doing something completely unrelated for a while.

Other than that pretty typically starting from drums/bass/vocals and trying to fill in around that.  But that's on an ideal day for me - more often it's just getting excited about something I heard, getting an idea, and playing around with the mix a lot.  I'm pretty early on in the journey with mixing relatively but realized I was getting burned out already if I didn't continue experimenting and playing around with a song the way I did when I first got interested in this in the first place.  Usually trying new things on every single mix because I have the luxury of usually not being up against the clock working on indie releases.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Case dependent on song of course but generally 3 phases

1) Clean - clean up obvious issues, noise, excessive low end, overly roomy, overly dynamic (sometimes completely raw like this might have 20-30db or higher swings in dynamic range between sections) clip gain

2) Dynamics and EQ in track context - compress and EQ how you usually would for what's appropriate

3) Stylize - effects, saturation, stylized EQ

author: cian riordan
content:
Process/Theory:
I see lots of people’s previous responses say they begin with getting the overheads to sound great and then start blending in close mics. If the drums were recorded by someone who knew what they were doing, with a good sounding kit, in a nice room — this would be a wonderful way to approach things. However 90% of the time that’s not the case with tracks that come my way. So I’m solving fro two problems — making the drums:
1) The foundational rhythm element. It doesn’t matter how good tonally your drums sound, they need to fill specific duties to carry the rhythm of the song. This is usually problem solving with phase within the elements of the drum set and then mostly getting the kick and snare to sit right around the rest of the instruments. Literally getting the right transients in the right frequency ranges — agnostic of ‘tone’ and ‘vibe’.
2) The sense of space for the mix. The drums are a huge part of this… and the foundation for the aesthetic of a mix. Is it a tight space? Big verby snare? This is all great, but will rarely deal with this stuff until #1 is taken care of. So my process starts with close mics.

After poking around and listening to the close mic various options to get a sense of what I’m working with, I’ll start with getting everything in phase. Solo the kick drum mics and get those in phase with each-other. If they don’t add up, I’ll start playing with HP filters at various Q’s to try and get things closer. You’d be surprised what you can get away with even when things are even 90 degrees out. Then, I’ll start introducing more spot mics (snare, toms, HH) and start getting things in focus with just phase flips. By the time you get to the overheads and rooms, you should have all the spot mics in phase with each-other so then you can get a better sense of how the overheads are going to play into the game.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love (trying) to explain this because it always makes me think of new things to try.

You can stereoize a sound using lots of techniques, the main three being pitch, delay, and phase. Often times your favorite plugins will do combos of these, so flipping the phase on one side will sometimes kill some of your wideness.

It's worth doing a google, but something like a flanger is simply duplicating the signal and micro delaying one of them at a variable rate. So the duplicated signal might oscillate between 2-20 milliseconds, which makes that crazy flanger sound. If you take that duplicated signal and run it through an aggressive filter (which will introduce some phase shift) and that's what a phaser is. 

You can play with multiple duplicate signals, flipping phase on one side and getting wild effects. You can play with pitch on the delayed signal and start getting an effect we call "chorus." But of course, each of these types of effects are just combinations of fundamental ways to manipulate audio. Many combos are possible!

Hooray sound design!

Also, I would love @Slow Hand to correct and expand, since I know he (and many others on here) are REAL sound design nerds.

author: LAPhill
content:
Are you looking for resources on writing/production, or mixing? Just like with the record side, there's so much noise from bedroom composers and people that have zero real-world experience. And as Ruairi is always saying, even the people with real success often can't teach what they know. Maybe I'm a bit cranky after an 8 hour delay at the airport yesterday, but Spitfire has gotten quite good at creating "tutorial" videos that are thinly veiled advertisements, and many of their libraries are the equivalent of one-knob plugins or CLA vocals. Selling paint-by-numbers solutions to naïve kids who want to get into scoring (They're far from the only ones guilty of this). But to focus on some of the channels I think are actually worth their salt:

8-Bit Music Theory: https://www.youtube.com/@8bitMusicTheory/videos
Can be a bit basic at times, but he talks a lot about structure which, IMO, is becoming a lost art in modern scoring.

Anne-Kathrin Dern: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWJg1w7F3PKPbSpEF2YOejVjWAg-KcM3Z
Not the biggest name out there, but she has a no-bullshit way of explaining things about orchestration and theory that is clear and concise. As far as "teachers," I think she's a good one.

Alan Meyerson Waves Sessions: https://youtu.be/h9jZqn5lnw4
I hesitate to include this. I know for a fact that Alan swapped out a bunch of his go-to plugins to make everything a Waves product. I haven't watched this in awhile, but it's a good insight into how he sets up a big mix session and why he makes some of his decisions. He's also playing to the camera/audience some, so this is a your-mileage-may-vary recommendation.

McGowen Soundworks: https://www.youtube.com/@McGowanSoundworks/featured
Phil knows his shit, and goes pretty deep breaking down a few actual mixes, which is pretty rare to find.

If I think of others, I'll report back. Hope that helps

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Hey howdy hey. Stream of consciousness response here:

First of all- great question. Haven’t seen you around these parts yet so I don’t know your situation and can’t speak to your specifics. But, there are some overarching philosophical ideas worth considering. 

1) the answer to each of these questions is different for every person. None of us got into music because we’re risk averse and looking for stability, so dont think just cause you’re “going full time” or you start calling it a “career” that somehow that will be different. 

2) and this is universally true, you’ll never be younger or have fewer responsibilities than you do now.

3) don’t take the leap if you’re not willing to: be poor. Have roommates. Eat ramen. Breakup with girlfriends/boyfriends who expect more from you. Borrow money for your cellphone bill. Drive a shitty car. Etc etc. 

But also, if you don’t bet on yourself, no one else is going to either.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When successful music producers talk about "mentors," it's almost always working under someone. This usually starts out as an internship or assistant position of some sort. Some come through your network of music friends, some come from doing exceptional work and people further along in their career taking notice, and some come from applying to the various "looking for an assistant with xyz qualifications" posts you see here and on social media.

I made an album with a local band called the Matches up in Oakland. They started getting attention from record labels and big producers in LA. I moved to LA and met Eric Valentine who liked the album and met with the band. I asked if I could intern for him. He said he didn't have interns but I should stay in touch cause sometimes they hired extra help. I called him every two weeks for the next six months until an opportunity opened up. Then I assisted him for five years while making indie records on the side.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
My advice is to have in person interactions as much as possible. When it comes to making records at a super high level (intense, stressful, high standards, egos, deadlines, freakouts, etc), you need to build a level of trust that for me is impossible without spending time with a person.

It doesn't mean you can't build a career remotely, but it's harder. Not only is it harder to build trust, but the remote option is available to anyone with an internet connection. So you're competing with a much larger pool of people too.

Does that mean move to LA or London or Miami or wherever? Not necessarily. But finding a way to get in person with the kinds of people you want to work with is extremely important

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Another way to see this, at least the harmonics that clipping adds, is considering a simple sin wave vs a square wave. Read into the harmonics created (it’s just wave theory). But it’s especially clear in synthesis in that case.

Of course musical applications are much more complex, but that’s why clipping (squaring off the top of a rounded waveform) adds harmonics

That’s what people mean when they say it spreads the energy across the spectrum. In the case of a sin wave, you have a single fundamental. At the far other end, you have a square wave which has harmonics all up the spectrum of frequency

author: cian riordan
content:
I would tell them there's a few things to consider when pressing vinyl:
1) Mastering is especially important as it’s the real bridge between the music and the mechanical production of the record. I had the great pleasure of mastering a few records for vinyl with Doug Sax (give him a google) and there’s a lot more to the process than modern mastering for digital services. They will actually cut the acetate disc which will be what manufacturers use to make the metal stamper that actually molds the records. A lot of thought goes into this process such as the width of the grooves to accommodate bass frequencies, etc. If you want a good sounding record, there’s no way around working with a seasoned professional.

2) Side lengths are important, as is track order. The more music you put on a side of vinyl, the less fidelity it will have as a whole. There will be sacrifices in the manufacturing to accommodate all of the music, so it’s best to keep your side lengths under 20 mins. Closer to 15 mins per side is ideal sonically, but sometimes that means doing double records and that just gets expensive. Also the order in which the tracks play on each side plays a part. The songs at the beginning of the side have more bandwidth and less distortion… it basically diminishes the closer you get to the center. Whatever the last track on the side is will just sound worse. It’s a flaw in the medium… so think about that.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Power question:

I just had a power strip completely die - and I think melt slightly! All the gear was totally protected (pretty nice power strip, but old at this point).  It had my Computer, my PMC twotwo8's, a synth, some other odds and ends plugged into it.

So, what are some best practices when it comes to power/electrical and recording/music gear? Does it really matter if things are on separate outlets if they all go to the same breaker? and if they are on separate breakers and then interconnecting later on, isn't there potential for ground loops / noise?

This is the first time I've had one completely fry - I've had things shut off but nothing like this.

author: David Fuller
content: That power strip probably had an internal short. Admittedly, I'm a little leery of running that much stuff off one circuit, especially stuff that draws lots of current on the same strip like the monitors and the computer.

author: KushKadett

maybe not a newb question but I thought it was really interesting what Jon said in regards to distortion of converters. I noticed something similar by experimenting with different clocks on my rather cheap interface. 
One being the internal clock and the other a high quality Antelope Isochrone clock. The minute I hooked it up I was able to monitor a lot louder without it having the feeling of hurting my ears- the increase in clarity was immediate. 
So It seems to be the case that this subtle (intermodulation?) distortion literally hurts our ears and can make people go deaf. 40 of Drake was saying something similar, so I'm wondering if there's more to this.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Just a place to start - learn and practice all of the scale modes (Ionian, mixolydian, aeolian etc) and basic chords. (Major, minor, augmented, diminished, etc) 

Frankly you can start with just basic 3 note chord and expand to bigger chords and inversions. I am by no means an expert but I am a long time guitarist with 0 theory that learned theory via piano playing so hopefully this might give you a very basic direction rather than something overly technical.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I use a smart plug to turn on and off my noisy raid archive drives each night via a Furman power conditioner. They mount when the plug turns on, then Keyboard maestro ejects them a few hours later, and they turn off with HomeKit automation. I was tired of coming down to work and having the drives humming super loud when I walk in. 

I want to get another plug for my other Furman that powers my Apollo and monitors. I do turn off the Furman switch instead of individual components. 

All that to say, you should be good to use a smart switch for something like this. I have the WeMo plug currently. The only caution is that it’s often “good practice” to turn off your monitors before anything else, although modern gear seems a bit better about not popping your monitors!

Should just be two steps:

On 3rd party plugins in live that allow sidechaining, you should see this little Sidechain menu show up.  So this should look really similar to the sidechain settings in the stock compressor. (1st picture)

Next, inside the plugin there should be an option to change the source of the sidechain to "external" from default internal. I don't have F6 but looking up an image of the plugin it looks like the option is in the bottom right (2nd picture).

If that doesn't work then I'm not sure what's going wrong.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **More samples (slices) per second equals a better representation of the analog waveform.** Within half the band of the sample rate (say up to 22.05k for 44.1k) this is demonstrably not true. I know that is confounding, but digital and information theory is basically miraculous
- **We can hear/feel/sense sounds above 20k.** We truly really cannot and if you experiment with significant energy above 20k you’ll actually see problems creep in for electronics and speakers etc. Information above 20k is not our friend (space for harmonic information to live without aliasing back excepted)
- **Working at multiples of 44.1k is better because the sample rate conversion will work better.** This used to be a little bit true a long time ago but hasn’t been for a long time. Use the SRC in iZotope RX on it’s stock preset to 44.1 and you are in pretty good shape
- **Digital EQs work better at higher sample rates because of cramping.** Cramping was an esoteric problem with older digital EQs that looked bad on analyzers but never actually sounded very bad. It’s a solved problem nowadays with most EQs.
- **Video and film is at 48k so we must start there.** Yes film and TV still work at 48k (although YouTube specs 44.1 now) but I have sent a million tracks for sync at 44.1 and it gets dropped in with SRC and away we go

author: Ross Fortune
content:
**General**

Interview style material can be great, and sources like Mix With The Masters where you can watch legitimate professionals working while they explain why they do what they do. Of course, you first need to understand the tools in order to understand why people use them in certain ways in specific situations, so building your knowledge of the fundamentals is important.

In general beware of anything with hyped titles like “30 MIXING HACKS I WISH I KNEW”. The internet is awash with misinformation, so it’s important to assess who the information is coming from, and what their agenda may be (whether that’s building subscribers, or shilling a product etc). If in doubt, research the records these people have worked on, and listen to them to see if you actually like how they sound!


**Engineering/Mixing/Production**

Steve Albini / Electrical Audio: https://www.youtube.com/@ElectricalAudioOfficial

Making records with Eric Valentine: https://www.youtube.com/@mrwev

Just For The Record - Mixing/interview streams - https://www.youtube.com/@JFTRLive

Sol State - Clips from longer form streams by (mostly electronic and pop) producers - https://www.youtube.com/@SolStateMusic

Live With Matt Rad (focused around Instagram Live interviews, with a generous community on Discord - generally skewing towards pop)
Insta: https://www.instagram.com/livewithmattrad/
Discord: https://discord.com/invite/fcfEtxRbWT
Podcast on Spotify, Apple Music etc.
YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@LivewithMattRad
YouTube Clips Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCs8ZKTveuxghTN-QaHFemsw

author: bobby k
content: Let me preface by saying nothing tangible has got me feeling down or discouraged. In fact I think I'm in the best season of my life so far and it feels like everything is going right (aside: aren't you more likely to self sabotage when things are good than when they are bad?) to zoom out a little bit, i already know the answer. I'm doing too much at once, spreading myself thin beyond enjoyment. in the grit of a transition and it's clear where I'm going but I have no frame of reference for the timeline. A few years ago, I was mid-20s, in a band on a major, had roommates & cheap rent, and a chess app addiction. i was still a "professional" but things were extremely simple. in short, left the band, spent a few years mixing much more than producing, and now am swinging back that way. I'm about to turn 30, I have a mortgage, a (semi) dependent, my first real studio, an intern to set an example for, 5ish mixing clients at any moment, producing for 3 artists and co-prod/consulting on 2 other projects, playing occasionally in any of 4 different bands, and producing/recording some live performances (as well as starting a YT channel in this lane). In my experience at least, it really seems like something shifted at the top of this year, and I hate to say it but part of the fault is TikTok (is the rest of the fault mine?). Everything is urgent to everyone and nothing informs each other or oscillates together. It feels like a clock is constantly going "tick, tock, tick, tock" and the anxiety I once had over money is shifted completely towards my time management. Every time I look away from my phone I have 30 new texts. I think I'm crushing it in my professional demands but I don't know that I'm being the person I want to be for my friends, family and partner. I don't know that I'm setting a good example to this intern. I don't know that I'm there to take care of myself all the way.

author: cian riordan
content: Pros and cons, like anything else. Open back tend to have a more neutral response… almost closer to being on speakers. Less fatiguing. Downside is lack of isolation from outside world, lack of low/high end “hype”. Neither are a panacea and both will have their issues with translation to the outside world. I can mix in headphones because I’ve mixed in good sounding rooms as built up good practices - with good results - for 20 years. But it isn’t my ideal. I would almost always trust a decent sounding — even unideal room before solely relying on them.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
@oaklandmatt , your experience with EV is really interesting and makes me think about cultural differences. This question goes out to anyone with experience in this. I’d love to have a mentor too. I’ve been a musician since I was a kid, producing for 17 years and mixing for about 10. Even though I make a good living from this, I’ve always missed having a mentor figure.

In my country there aren’t many role models, so I’ve always looked to the UK/US. That makes me wonder if my approach fits the Anglo world. I’ve written to mixers I really admire, offering remote assistant work in exchange for learning, but most already have assistants or aren’t interested. I get it—I’ve been approached the same way, and I can’t always afford or fully trust an assistant either.

A producer with big credits was very generous with me, taught me a lot, and said he’d keep me in mind. Once he even contacted me for some drum edits on a known band’s record, but he ended up doing it himself because he was in a rush. Over two years, I only reminded him twice that I was available. So when I read that you used to call EV every two weeks, it honestly blows my mind. That’s where my question about cultural differences comes from

In my country that would feel inappropriate, but I often notice that in the Anglo world, insisting (within reason) isn’t seen as a bad thing. Any advice? I’m pretty shy and always afraid of coming off as annoying. I’d love to hear your thoughts guys

author: masteredbyjack
content:
To illustrate a good example of the difference and why (guessing) Jon would want to clip rather than do this (which would control the transients as you describe)

If you use a long look ahead, call it a limiter with a long look ahead. That will let the processor know about the transient well before it hits the GR circuit, thus avoiding distortion/harmonics (of course there still could be some artifacts). But even though there will be samples at the threshold, it won’t be a straight line waveform as if you clipped it. It is pushing the waveform down. The waveform itself is actually changed still, so it is not exact but it’s different than clipping.

A clipper just squares it off. Hence harmonics.

This is why you can limit/compress an instrument like piano, which has a tendency to hear distortion easily, when clipping it would be a disaster (unless you are going for that)
